description:
Sub-species of Homo.

Behaviorally modern humans. H. sapiens is the only surviving species of the genus Homo. Modern humans are the subspecies Homo sapiens sapiens, which differentiates them from what has been argued to be their direct ancestor, Homo sapiens idaltu. Includes such fossils as Ötzi the Iceman and Cheddar Man
name: Homo sapiens sapiens

description:
Species of Homo.

Anatomically modern humans. Includes Cro-Magnon, Klasies River Caves, and Omo. May include the Red Deer Cave.
name: Homo sapiens

description:
From the latin, "human being", this clade started with H. habilis in the Piacenzian, and one species exists today.  It is descended from the australopithecines, possibly A. garhi. 

( Linnaeus, 1758 )

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homo

http://bio.sunyorange.edu/updated2/creationism/macroevolution/3%20The%20Cranium.htm
name: Homo

description: Sub-tribe of the hominid primates.
name: Hominina

description: Tribe of Homininae
name: Unnamed Hominini 01

description:
One subset of Hominidae is the tribe, Hominini - bi-pedal "humanoid" hominids. 

Everything about the earliest hominines is transitional from the relative sizes of their brains to the location of their brain stem, which is at the bottom of the balanced skull, forcing it to move bipedally.  But so are the knees and pelvic region definitely bipedal, and adapted from an originally quadrupedal structure, which is one explanation for why so many people develop lower back problems.
name: Hominini

description: Sub-family of Humans, Gorillas and Chimpanzees.
name: Homininae

description:
One subset of Hominoidea is Hominidae, (Great apes).  The "great" apes) aren't just "large apes". There are more distinguishing features than just their size. For one thing, although all of them, including humans, have the same number of hair follicles all over their bodies, they are described as having more sparse hair than "lesser apes" or non-hominid monkeys. But they also have an unprecedented brain-size-to-body mass of any animal on Earth. Consequently, they also have the most complex socio-emotional relationships of any other "social animal.  All apes also share a unique dentition of 2 incisors, 1 canine, 2 premolars, and 3 molars in each quarter of the mouth. In most cases, the canine is reduced, almost useless as a cynodont tooth. And the molars are also unique in all the animal kingdom. Every ape has them, and only apes have them. Each molar comes to five points interrupted by a Y-shaped crevasse. If you want to know what that looks like, go to a mirror and open your mouth real wide.  When you do that, also look at the dome-shape in the roof of your mouth. Therein lies the only significant difference between humans and the other apes that are still alive. That shape, that bit of space above the tongue that the other apes don't have, is what allows us to form words. None of the other great apes can speak because of that little extra space in the mouth which only we possess. But other apes are all capable of complex communication either by their own body language in addition to grunts and squeals with particular meanings, or by learned forms of sign language or symbols taught to them. Koko the gorilla is the most famous of the articulate signing non-human apes. Washoe the chimpanzee and Chantek the orangutan are other famous examples, and of course there are many more around the world who are not so well-known. These beings definitely aren't just mimicking their owners, nor are they "trained" to appear as if they really know what they're saying. This is no stupid pet trick. All of them have been repeatedly proven to possess sufficient cognitive skills and comprehension of the meanings of their words, and they may know more than a thousand of them. And they all use these words to express personal feelings, love and compassion, and all of them grieve for their loved ones who have died. One of them, Michael, Koko's life mate, even remembered his mother being killed on the day he was captured. Upon his death, one of Koko's human visitors told her that Mike was now an angel, to which the grieving gorilla responded "Imagine".  They're not as intelligent as we are because our frontal lobes are larger than any of theirs. But they are definitely intelligent, even sentient beings. Even among the smartest creatures on earth, we are still the smartest by far. But we are not so unique, nor so far above them that we are not still one of them.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?


v=DZv8VyIQ7YU&feature=youtu.be&fbclid=IwAR0R4S8T5iFXc2XDEwClgFMgFE8SzhiemhuL1b190dwom4aOmVMHo1Wy8w4
name: Hominidae

description: Hominoids (apes) emerged from within Propliopithecoidea, and are another subset of Old World monkeys, all with uniquely distinctive fingerprints. But there are specific differences between them and all other tailless monkeys so that it is possible to tell an ape from other Catarrhines. Apes have a broader chest, and even less olfactory capacity (ability to scent) than other monkeys, and their dentition shows traits unique to that clade. They all also show a greater tendency toward bipedality, and some species apart from humans are exclusively bipedal, at least on the ground.  One commonality they all have, and which they still share with most "lesser" monkeys, are their ears. Nothing else in the animal kingdom has ears like the ones we share with every other ape. Another trait that is distinctly "ape" is that they're all capable of brachiation, (hanging or swinging only from the arms) due to a greatly-increased occipital arc (shoulder rotation) which other monkeys don't have, and can't do, or can't do nearly as well.
name: Hominoidea

description:
One subset of Anthropoidea is Catarrhini, (Old World monkeys) 

Catarrhines are a specific simian group, recognizable in fossils by the fact that they have only two premolars (cuspids & bicuspids) while New World monkeys (of the order, Platyrrhini) have three. Old World monkeys are actually "newer" in some respects than the 'New World monkeys. New World monkeys actually have more "primtive" features than Old World monkeys do. One of these are the splayed position of the nostrils. Old World monkeys have downward turned nostrils, and most of them have a recognizable nose. None of this group has claws. All of their nails are as flat and harmless as our own. For grasping, they've replaced their claws with sensative fingertips, and each of them bears a uniquely distinctive fingerprint as well, particularly in certain subgroups. In Platyrrhines, the tail is usually long and prehensile. But among Catarrhines, the tail is effectively useless and unimportant since most of these monkeys now live on the ground. Some Catarrhines have weak, wispy tails, some have short stubs for a tail, and many don't have any tail at all. 

Modern catarrhine species which are traditionally recognized as "monkeys" are all Cercopithecids. But there is another, much older group called Propliopithecoidea, from which we have found many fossil species dating from 14 million to 34 million years old. Among them are the apparent ancestors of Hominoidea: including Aegyptopithecus, described as an ape-like monkey, and Proconsul, described as a monkey-like ape.
name: Catarrhini

description:
AKA Anthropoidea (monkeys) 
Monkeys are a more advanced subset of Haplorhines. They have only two actual breasts, pectoral mammae which are unlike those of any other mammal. And unlike lemurs, most monkeys have completely lost the ability to move their ears. Only a few individuals remain who can even wiggle them anymore. Monkeys also lack the specialized sensory whiskers and the wet nose that lemurs and so many "lesser" animals have. Among the other obvious external differences are that male monkeys' genetalia are naked and pendulous in that they're not thethered to their abdomens anymore, as they are on most other eutherians. They have a tendency toward bipedalism.  Like most bats, but unlike lemurs, monkeys usually have a flatter face, and all monkeys have completely forward-facing binocular eyes and trichromatic vision, meaning that monkeys can see in color where lemurs, and most other mammals can't. Monkeys have other internal distinctions from prosimians too. They all have a well-developed caecum, which is a sort of distension in the digestive tract that is mildly advantageous. But they have detrimental mutations too. All anthropoids have lost the ability to synthesize either vitamin D3 or vitamin C, and need to supplement both of these in their diet or they'll succumb to a condition of malnutrition commonly known as scurvy. 

Bahinia, Eosimias, and Amphipithecus are each protoanthropoids from the Eocene. Apidium is popularly considered to be both a parapithecid “monkey” and a potential ancestor of all other monkeys as well as apes and humans. As an online tutorial about early primate evolution maintained by Dennis O’Neil of Palomar College states, "Monkeys evolved during the early Oligocene or possibly near the end of the Eocene. Their ancestors were most likely prosimians. These monkeys were the first species of our infraorder—the Anthropoidea".

In a monophyletic classification system, everything in this clade is a monkey or a descendant of a monkey. And since there is no way to determine when the descendants of monkeys aren't monkeys anymore, then all their descendants should still be monkeys. Because again, monkeys can be defined by all of these characters, or they can be defined by a collective tally of them as "members of the clade, "Anthropoidea" (or Simiiformes). Either way, humans may be really big smart monkeys.  But we are still monkeys in the same way that lions are cats, the way that ducks are birds.
name: Simiiformes

Prozostrodontia
description:
Includes mammals; Reduced prefrontal and postorbital bones, with a reduction or disappearance of postorbital bar seperating eye socket from temporal region

Sagittal crest extending along top of skull, connecting to lambdoial crest at back skull

Sphenopalatine foramen present

Unfused dentary symphysis

Inner side coronoid process is mediolaterally thick

Lower postcanine roots are divided with multiple roots

neural spines of dorsal vertebrae angled backward

Lesser trochanter positioned close to head of femur

Some changes to pelvic reigon for more upright running

Lateral surface of iliac blade is conves and divided by longitudinal ridge into dorsal & ventral portions

Posterior iliac spine reduced, lies anterior to acetabulum

Cotyloid(acetabular) notch: lies entirely on ischium, between acetabular facet & pubic process

description:
"dog teeth" first appeared in the late Permian, and their mammal descendants still exist today.  They have a lot of distinguishing characteristics, including an at least partial secondary palate, smooth canines and ridged incisors, and a large dentary and smaller post-dentary bones.  http://palaeos.com/vertebrates/cynodontia/cynodontia.html

(Owen, 1861)
name: Cynodontia

description: These protomammals appeared in the mid-Permian, and 1 lineage exists today.  All Eutheridonts have no teeth on the roof of their mouth (palate),  a small bone behind the eye (epipterygoid) expanded, and a narrower top of the skull.  Both child-clades convergently developed mammalian features, such as a secondary palate and a lack of a postorbital bar. (Hopson & Barghusen, 1986)
name: Eutheriodontia

description: "beast tooth" was named for their more mammal-like jaws and teeth. They first appeared in the mid-Permian, and exist to this day.
name: Theriodontia

description:
Includes amnodonts and theirodonts (including mammals)

(Hopson, 1999)
name: Neotherapsida

description:
Endothermic protomammals with pretty upright stances and more powerful jaws than their ancestors that began in the early Permian.  

(Broom, 1905)
name: Eutherapsida

description:
• Frontal orbital process extends far laterally (it is poorly developed, if present, in other synapsids) (Fig. 2C).
  • Deep prefrontal pocket (a concavity near the anterodorsal edge of the orbit).
  • Vomerine teeth absent (the vomer bears a shagreen of denticles in other synapsids).

description:
Comments

4 limbed vertebrates emerged in the late Devonian, and still exist today.

Gadow (1896) seems to be the first author to explicitly use Tetrapoda as it's currently generally conceived in scientific journal context, though an undergraduate comparative anatomy textbook published in the same year makes similar use of the name (Hatschek & Cori 1896). However, in subsequent work (Gadow 1898; Gadow 1911), Hans Gadow attributes the coinage of the name to Hermann Credner, presumably implied by the latter's Eotetrapoda (Credner 1891). While often credited for the coining of Tetrapoda, the scientific name Goodrich (1930) is unambiguously associated with in the literature is Cheiropterygii, a synonym for Tetrapoda (Ahlberg 1998, Damiani 2001).

It's worthy of note that the name 'Tetrapoda' has seen early usage in modern taxonomy for several other classificative concepts including a group of lizards (Haworth 1825), neotenous salamanders (Grant 1861), a genus of gall-mites (Bach 1870 fide Thomas 1876, Arctos Database 2018) and a suborder of mites (Trouessart 1892 fide Zhang 2017).

Taxonomic References
  • Gadow, Hans. (1896). "On the Evolution of the Vertebral Column of Amphibia and Amniota." Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Containing Papers of a Biological Character 187: 1-57. http://www.jstor.org/stable/91850. 
  • Hatschek, B.; Cori, K. (1896). Elementarcurs der zootomie in fünfzehn vorlesungen. Jena: G. Fischer.  
  • Gadow, Hans. (1898). A classification of Vertebrata, recent and extinct. London: Black.
  • Gadow, Hans. (1911). "Sauropsida" in Chisholm, Hugh. Encyclopædia Britannica (11th ed.). Cambridge University Press. Vol. 24: pp. 252-253. 
  • Credner, Hermann. (1891). "Die Urvierfüssler (Eotetrapoda) des sächsischen Rothliegenden". Allgemein-verständliche naturwissenschaftliche Abhandlungen 15. 52 p.
  • Goodrich, Edwin S. (1930). Studies on the structure & development of vertebrates. London: Macmillan and Co., Limited.
  • Ahlberg, P. E. (1998). "Postcranial stem tetrapod remains from the Devonian of Scat Craig, Morayshire, Scotland". Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 122(1-2), 99-141. 
  • Damiani, R. J. (2001). "A systematic revision and phylogenetic analysis of Triassic mastodonsauroids (Temnospondyli: Stereospondyli)". Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 133(4), 379-482. 
  • Haworth, A. H. (1825). "A binary arrangement of the class amphibia". The Philosophical Magazine, 65(325), 372-373. 
  • Grant, R.E. (1861). Tabular view of the primary divisions of the Animal Kingdom, intended to serve as an outline of an elementary course of recent Zoology, etc. (London): i-vi, 1-91. 
  • Thomas, Friedrich August Wilhelm. 1876. Beschreibung neuer oder minder gekannter acrocecidien (phytoptus-gallen). Dresden: K. Blochmann & Sohn.
  • Arctos Database. (2018). "Taxonomy Details: Tetrapoda". Accessed 2018-11-21. <http://arctos.database.museum/name/Tetrapoda#GBIFBackboneTaxonomy> 
  • Zhang, Z. Q. (2017). "Eriophyoidea and allies: where do they belong?". Systematic and Applied Acarology, 22(8), 1091-1095.

description:
"Whole Animal"

Examples: All animals and their most closely related unicellular sisters (e.g. choanoflagellates, filastereans, and ichthyosporeans). The unicellular holozoans are mostly parasites. 

Sister clade: Holomycota (fungi) 

Earliest fossil evidence: 970 million years (1)

Origins: A 2011 multigene analysis indicates that holozoans emerged around 1100 mya (2)

1)  Aleshin VV, Konstantinova AV, Mikhailov KV, Nikitin MA, Petrov NB (December 2007). "Do we need many genes for phylogenetic inference?". Biochemistry Mosc. 72 (12): 1313–23. doi:10.1134/S000629790712005X. PMID 18205615. 

2)   Porter, Suzannah M. (2004). "The fossil record of early eukaryotic diversification". Paleontological Society Papers. 10: 35–50. 

2)   Parfrey, Laura Wegener; Lahr, Daniel J. G.; Knoll, Andrew H.; Katz, Laura A. (16 August 2011). "Estimating the timing of early eukaryotic diversification with multigene molecular clocks". Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. 108 (33): 13624–13629. doi:10.1073/pnas.1110633108. ISSN 0027-8424. PMC 3158185. PMID 21810989.

description:
Etymology

Eukaryota is French, based on Greek breakdown.

Meaning

Eu - Easily formed/well/good; Karyote - nut/kernal. Well formed nut.

Overview

About a billion years after the formation of our planet, living organisms appear on earth about 3.5 BYA and fill the earth within another 500 MY. Eukaryotes evolve after a further 500 MY. All living organisms except bacteria and archaea are currently listed as Eukarya. This includes animals, plants, fungi and protists. Protists are often referred to as the junk box for organisms not easily located within other kingdoms and may include multiple kingdoms in themselves. 

Defining features, key features and its evolutionary origin

Any organism whose cells contain a nucleus and other organelles enclosed within a membrane. Eukaryotic innovations include the cell cycle complete with a chromosome segregation apparatus, sexual reproduction complete with recombination, a cytoskeleton, spliceosomes and introns, small regulatory RNAs, vesicular transport based on membrane proteins, serine/threonine/tyrosine kinase signaling networks, the use of ubiquitin in post-translational protein modification, and a variety of new genes. See the images below and if you click on any (or the sunnyorange.eu link), and it will lead you to a page which explains multiple possible origins for Eukaryotes. Whilst many believe that Eukaryotes evolved from the super-domain, Prokaryotes, some consider that Eukaryotes may have evolved into Prokaryotes or that all three domains arose simultaneously.  

Clade divisions

Bacteria and Archaea are the other two domains/clade branches.  

Who named it and when?

Chatton (1925); Whitaker and Margulis (1978) Chatton, E. 1925. Pansporella perplexa. Re´flexions sur la biologie et la phyloge´nie des protozoaires. Ann. Sci. Nat. Zool. 10e serie, VII:1–84 Whittaker, R. H., & Margulis, L. (1978). Protist classification and the kingdoms of organisms. Biosystems, 10(1-2), 3-18.  Geological period - epoch/era. Precambrian, as far back as the proterozoic, (early paleoproterozoic) or even late Archaen.  

Examples

Animals, plants, fungi and some miscellaneous/protists. 

First origin evolved

3000-1650 MYA.  

Earliest evidence/example(s)

3000, 2700 (stem versions) to 1200 MYA (with clearly modern group relationships).

Debate/controversy

There are significant numbers of not-fully categorised organisms which are placed within protists and the classification will change over time. The evolution of Eukaryotes likely began at least 2 billion years ago. Acritarchs are clearly evidenced from fossils 1650 mya.  Grypania algae from 2100 MYA and Geosiphon type  fungus, Diskagma has been found in paleosols, 2200 MYA. Biomarkers (in this case, the presence of steranes, particularly cholestane and its 28- to 30-carbon analogs), provides persuasive evidence for the existence of eukaryotes 500 million to 1 billion years before the extant fossil record indicates that the lineage arose.
